questions.text: Which of the following are not included among the minor criteria of the modified Duke criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis?

choices.text: Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii

questions.solution:
Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii is one of the major criteria of modified Duke criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis. All other options are minor criteria.

Infective endocarditis is associated with bacterial or fungal infection of the valvular or endocardial surface of the heart. The definitive diagnosis can only be established by histological and microbiological examinations of the vegetation.

However, a diagnostic schema called, modified Duke criteria, is usually used for diagnosis. The criteria are based on clinical, laboratory, and echocardiographic findings commonly encountered in patients with endocarditis, as described below.

The diagnosis is made based on the presence of

  • Two major criteria, or
  • One major and three minor criteria, or
  • Five minor criteria.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criteria for severe acute malnutrition?

choices.text: Weight for height less than -3 SD
Weight for age less than -3 SD

questions.solution:
Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) according to the WHO criteria is the weight for height (not age) less than minus -3 SD.

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by the WHO as any of the following:

  • Weight-for-length (or height) below −3 SD of the WHO child growth standards
  • Presence of bipedal edema
  • Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) <11.5 cm. 

Management of SAM is given below:

questions.text: A diabetic patient with foci of infection was diagnosed with systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS). Which of the following is not included under the diagnostic criteria for SIRS?
questions.solution:
Bradycardia is not a part of SIRS criteria. 

SIRS is diagnosed when two of the following are present:

  • Hyperthermia (temperature >38°C) or hypothermia (temperature <36°C)
  • Tachypnea (>20 breaths/min) or arterial carbon dioxide tension (PaCO2) of less than 32 mm Hg
  • Tachycardia (>90 beats/min) 
  • White cell count >12 x 109/L or <4 x 109/L or >10% Band forms

Sepsis is SIRS with a documented infection.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with nausea, vomiting, and acute onset epigastric pain radiating to the back. Investigations revealed elevated levels of serum amylase and lipase. An abdominal X-ray showed the colon-cut off sign.  Which of the following criteria uses CT to stage the severity of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the abdominal radiograph showing the colon cut-off sign are suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Balthazar Scoring is used for staging the severity of acute pancreatitis based on CT findings.

The most common causes of acute pancreatitis are - gallstones, alcoholism, post-ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography), drugs (steroids, thiazides, azathioprine, etc.), hypercalcemia, etc. 

The classical presentation includes acute severe epigastric pain radiating to the back and relieved by leaning forward. Nausea and vomiting can also be present. Clinical signs such as hypotension, tachycardia, Grey Turner sign (bluish discoloration of the flanks), and Cullen’s sign (bluish discoloration around the umbilicus) can be present.

The Grey Turner sign is shown below:

Cullen's sign is shown below:

The below abdominal x-ray shows an abrupt transition from distended to collapsed colon just beyond the splenic flexure. This is known as a colon cut-off sign.

Laboratory findings include elevated serum amylase and serum lipase. Serum amylase levels are non-specific, while serum lipase is more specific, and lipase is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours from the onset of symptoms.

Management involves keeping the patient nil per oral, fluid replacement, and pain control. Antibiotics are rarely required unless the infection spreads.

Other options-

Option A: Modified Glasgow score uses 8 laboratory findings to predict the severity of acute pancreatitis (within 48 hours of treatment onset). It is not a CT-based scoring system.

Option C: APACHE II score (Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation score) is another clinical tool that assesses the risk of mortality and predicts prolonged intensive care treatment. It is also not CT-based.

Option D: Ranson's criteria uses 11 clinical and laboratory findings at admission and after 48 hours to assess clinical severity. It does not include CT scan findings.

  • 0 to 2 points: 0% to 3% mortality

questions.text: During your ICU posting, your senior resident advises you to extubate the patients, who are on mechanical ventilation and are found to be improving. In order to plan for weaning, the rapid shallow breathing index of the patient should be:
questions.solution:
Rapid shallow breathing index (RSBI) should be less than 100.

Patients with an RSBI <100 are eligible candidates for successful extubation. But, those with an RSBI >120 will need some degree of mechanical ventilator support.

A patient on mechanical ventilation should be tried to wean off when the patient no longer requires the ventilator. This condition usually met when the patient can breathe spontaneously, is hemodynamically stable with adequate arterial oxygen saturation, and when he has a pH >7.25.

Additional criteria include,

  • Inspiratory pressure: -20-30cm H2O
  • Tidal volume: 4-6ml/kg
  • Vital capacity: >10 mL/kg
  • Minute ventilation: <10 L/min
  • Rapid shallow breathing index(RSBI): <100

Patients are weaned off from the ventilator with the help of techniques such as pressure support, synchronized intermittent mandatory ventilation (SIMV), and periods of spontaneous breathing (either on a Τ-piece or on a low setting of CPAP).

Related Pearl: Mechanical Criteria for Weaning or Extubation

  • Inspiratory pressure: -20 to -30cm H2O
  • Tidal volume: 4-6ml/kg
  • Vital capacity: >10 mL/kg
  • Minute ventilation: 10L/min
  • Rapid shallow breathing index: <100

questions.text: Which of the following options is incorrect regarding ROME IV criteria?

choices.text: Recurrent abdominal pain, on average should be present for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months
Associated with a change in stool form
Associated with a change in stool frequency
Abdominal pain for the last 3 weeks with symptom onset at least 6 months before diagnosis.

questions.solution:
The ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS  must be fulfilled for the last 3 months with symptom onset at least 6 months before diagnosis.

The onset of symptoms during a period of stress or emotional upset is a feature that supports a diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).

Based on bowel movement patterns, IBS is classified as:

  • IBS-C: Irritable bowel syndrome-constipation predominant
  • IBS-D: Irritable bowel syndrome-diarrhea predominant
  • IBS-M: Irritable bowel syndrome-mixed

Alteration in bowel habits (constipation/diarrhea) is the most consistent clinical feature in IBS. This means that a majority of people suffering from IBS have an alteration in bowel habits. The most common pattern is constipation alternating with diarrhea, usually with one of these symptoms predominating.

IBS is a clinical diagnosis that can be made without performing many tests if the patient presents with typical symptoms. However, it is recommended to perform the following tests in most patients to rule out other conditions:

  • Complete blood count
  • Sigmoidoscopic examination
  • Stool examination for ova and parasites
  • 3-week lactose-free diet
  • Fecal calprotectin levels help distinguish inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) from IBS

In patients >40 years, air-contrast barium enema or colonoscopy should also be performed.

Related Pearl: ROME IV Diagnostic criteria for IBS

According to the Rome IV criteria, IBS is defined as recurrent abdominal pain for at least 1 day per week in the last 3 months. It must be associated with 2 or more of the following criteria:

  • Related to defecation (improvement or worsening)
  • Associated with a change in stool frequency
  • Associated with a change in stool form (appearance)

The above criteria must be fulfilled for 3 months with onset of some symptoms at least 6 months before diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)

For abdominal pain

  • Antispasmodics - Dicyclomine
  • Tricyclic antidepressants - Amitriptyline, Imipramine
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Citalopram

For diarrhoea

  • Opiate - Loperamide
  • 5-HT3 antagonist - Alosetron
  • Bile acid sequestrant - Cholestyramine resin

For constipation

  • Laxatives such as psyllium/ispaghula husk and polyethylene glycol
  • Cl- channel activator - Lubiprostone
  • Guanylate cyclase agonist - Linaclotide
  • 5-HT4 agonist - Tegaserod
  • Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor - Paroxetine

questions.text: According to NADA's criteria, which of these findings would not be sufficient to consider the diagnosis of congenital heart disease in an infant?

choices.text: Presence of abnormal S2 and abnormal chest -X-ray
Presence of grade 3 systolic murmur alone

questions.solution:
According to NADA's criteria, the presence of abnormal ECG alone is not sufficient by itself to indicate congenital heart disease in an infant as it is a minor criteria. NADA’s criteria is used to diagnose congenital heart disease in children. questions.text: A 5-year-old child with Wilson's disease is being considered for liver transplantation. Which of the following is not a parameter in the selection criteria for transplantation?

choices.text: Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy

questions.solution:
A 5-year-old child with Wilson's disease is a case of non-paracetamol-induced acute liver failure and jaundice for more than 7 days before the development of encephalopathy is one of the parameters in the King's College criteria for liver transplantation.

It includes the following parameters:

Non-paracetamol-induced acute liver failure:

  • PT >100 s (INR >6.5)

        or/and

  • Any three of the following:
    • Age <10 years or >40 years
    • Etiology non-A, non-B hepatitis, or idiosyncratic drug reaction
    • Jaundice more than 7 days before the development of encephalopathy i.e., not hyperacute
    • PT >50 s (INR > 3.5)
    • Bilirubin > 18 mg/dl (300 μmol/L)

Paracetamol-induced acute liver failure:

  • pH <7.30 (irrespective of the grade of encephalopathy) 

        or/and

  • All three of the following:
    • Prothrombin time >100 s (INR >6.5)
    • Serum creatinine >3.4 mg/dl (300 μmol/L)
    • Grade 3 or 4 hepatic encephalopathy

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of cirrhosis presents with lethargy and disorientation to time. On examination, flapping tremors are noted. What is the most likely grading of hepatic encephalopathy in this patient according to West Haven criteria?
questions.solution:
Disorientation to time, and lethargy, in a known case of cirrhosis, suggest grade 2 hepatic encephalopathy according to West Haven criteria.

Hepatic encephalopathy is the alteration of mental status and cognitive function occurring in liver failure. This occurs due to the failure of removal of gut-derived neurotoxins like ammonia by liver. These neurotoxins enter the brain leading to the development of symptoms.

In patients with cirrhosis, encephalopathy is often found as a result of certain precipitating events such as hypokalemia, infection, an increased dietary protein load, or electrolyte disturbances.

Treatment of hepatic encephalopathy includes:

  • Correction of precipitating factors
  • Lactulose - Lactulose is a laxative that acts by getting converted to short chain fatty acid in the colon. These fatty acids result in decrease in pH of intestinal juice. At this low pH, ammonia becomes ionized and thus cannot be absorbed.
  • Rifaximin - It is a synthetic rifamycin that is poorly absorbed from the GIT and is indicated in the management of hepatic encephalopathy as it lowers the blood ammonia levels
  • Zinc - It serves as a co-factor for the urea cycle and thus stimulates it and lowers ammonia levels.

questions.text: As per the Milan criteria for liver transplantation in patients with cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma, which of the following would disqualify a patient for liver transplantation?

choices.text: Presence of a single tumor with diameter 4.2 cm
Presence of three tumors with diameters 2.5 cm, 2.2 cm, and 1.5 cm
Presence of two tumors with diameter 2.2 cm and 1.5 cm

questions.solution:
The presence of major vessel involvement would disqualify a patient for liver transplantation, as per the Milan criteria.

The Milan criteria are used to assess the suitability of patients with cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma for liver transplantation. In order to be suitable for liver transplantation, the patient should have

  • a single tumor with a diameter of ≤5 cm
  • up to 3 tumors, each with a diameter ≤3 cm
  • no extra-hepatic involvement
  • no macrovascular invasion

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of WHO's major criteria for the diagnosis of polycythemia vera?

choices.text: Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with panmyelosis

questions.solution:
Subnormal serum erythropoietin level is a minor criterion for the diagnosis of polycythemia vera. The other three options are included as major criteria for the diagnosis of polycythemia vera.

Polycythemia vera (PCV) is a hematopoietic stem cell disorder in which there is an accumulation of phenotypically normal red cells, granulocytes, and platelets in the absence of a recognizable physiologic stimulus. It is the most common myeloproliferative neoplasm. The increase in the red cells is predominantly responsible for the clinical symptoms in this condition.

In 15% to 20% of patients after an average period of 10 years, there is increased myelofibrosis and extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis. PCV transforms into AML in 2% of patients.

The most common cytogenetic abnormality in polycythemia vera is the JAK2 mutation. 

Clinical features of PCV:

  • Splenomegaly
  • Thrombocytosis - leads to venous arterial thrombosis, hepatic venous thrombosis. Erythromelalgia is the erythema, burning, and pain in the extremities. It also occurs due to thrombocytosis.
  • Erythrocytosis - leads to hyperviscosity, leading to neurologic symptoms such as vertigo, tinnitus, headache, visual disturbances, transient ischemic attacks (TIA), and systolic hypertension. 
  • Aquagenic pruritis
  • Hyperuricemia and gout - It may occur due to the large turnover of the hematopoietic stem cells

Diagnosis: Criteria for diagnosis is given below:

Major criteria:

  1. Hb more than 16.5g/dL in males and 16g/dL in females or hematocrit of >49% in men and >48% in women
  2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage growth (panmyelosis) including prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation.
  3. Presence of JAK-2 mutation

Minor criteria:

  • Subnormal erythropoietin levels.

Diagnosis requires all three major criteria or the first 2 major and 1 minor criterion.

Management:

  • Target Hb levels are < 14g/dL in males and < 12g/dL in females.
  • Periodic phlebotomy can be done to reduce hyperviscosity and to maintain the red cell mass. It is usually done at 3-month intervals.
  • Anticoagulants are given when there is thrombosis.
  • Allopurinol can be given to control hyperuricemia.
  • Ruxolitinib which is a nonspecific JAK2 inhibitor, pegylated IFN-α, or PUVA therapy can be used for intractable pruritis.
  • Ruxolitinib or pegylated IFN-α can be used to manage symptomatic splenomegaly.
  • Anagrelide which is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor is used to reduce platelet count in these patients.

Related Pearl: WHO Polycythemia Vera Criteria

Major criteria:

1. Hemoglobin >16.5 g/dL in men

     Hemoglobin >16.0 g/dL in women 

Or

     Hematocrit >49% in men

     Hematocrit >48% in women 

2. Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity with trilineage hyperplasia (panmyelosis) and prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic mature megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and 

3. Presence of JAK2 exon 12 mutation

Minor criterion:

Subnormal serum erythropoietin level

Diagnosis of polycythemia vera requires meeting either all 3 major criteria or the first 2 major criteria along with the minor criterion

questions.text: A  male patient presented with a fracture of the shaft of the femur following a road traffic accident. After 2 days he developed dyspnea, petechiae involving the whole body, and a fall in oxygen saturation. Fat embolism is suspected. Based on which criteria would he be diagnosed?
questions.solution:
Fat embolism syndrome is diagnosed based on Gurd's criteria.

Fat embolism is caused by the fat globules originating from the bone marrow following the fracture of long bones. Clinical features of fat embolism are usually seen within 72 hours. They include tachycardia, fever, breathlessness, petechiae, confusion, and restlessness.

There is no specific test for diagnosis. However, sputum and urine analysis to look for fat globules and monitoring of blood pO2 are done. Management of fat embolism is mostly supportive, with oxygen therapy. 

Other options:

Option B: Garden classification is used for fracture neck of the femur. It is based on the degree of displacement of the fracture.

Option C: Modified Wells Criteria is used to predict the likelihood of pulmonary embolism.

Option D: CURB-65 scoring is used to assess the severity of illness in a case of pneumonia, especially community-acquired pneumonia.

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Petechial rash
  • Respiratory symptoms with radiographic changes
  • CNS depression.

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia
  • Pyrexia
  • Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)
  • Renal abnormalities (oliguria, anuria, or lipiduria)
  • Acute thrombocytopenia
  • Acute decrease in hemoglobin
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Increased ESR

2 major criteria OR one major criteria + four minor criteria suggest a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: WHO criteria for blindness is visual acuity less than
questions.solution: According to the WHO, blindness is defined as presenting visual acuity of less than 3/60, or a corresponding visual field loss to less than 10° in the better eye.

questions.text: UK refinement of Hanifin and Rajka criteria is used in the diagnosis of which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
UK refinement of Hanifin and Rajka criteria is used in the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis.

The original Hanifin and Rajka criteria require that patients have at least 3 of the 4 major criteria and 3 of the 23 minor criteria. Consequently, Williams et al. coordinated a UK working party to attempt to refine the criteria of Hanifin and Rajka into a repeatable and validated set of diagnostic criteria for atopic eczema.

Related Pearl: UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (eczema)

In order to qualify as a case of atopic dermatitis (eczema) with the UK  diagnostic criteria, the child must have an itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child).

Plus three or more of the following:

  • Onset below age of 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
  • History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
  • History of a generally dry skin
  • Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first-degree relative in children under 4 years)
  • Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the obstetric criteria for diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome?

choices.text: ≥ 1 unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus ≥10 weeks
Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery <37 weeks
Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery <34 weeks

questions.solution:
Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery before 34 weeks(not <37 weeks) is an obstetric criterion for diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody (APLA) syndrome. 

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that is commonly associated with fetal death, preterm delivery, early-onset preeclampsia, and fetal growth restriction due to placental insufficiency and thromboses. Pregnancy loss usually occurs before ten weeks.

Diagnosis of APLA requires at least one clinical criterion and one laboratory criterion:

  • Clinical
    • Obstetric criteria - 
      • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond ten weeks, or
      • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery before 34 weeks or
      • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before ten weeks
    • Vascular - One or more episodes of arterial-venous or small vessel thrombosis in any organ or tissue
  • Laboratory criteria(2 positive tests at least 12 weeks apart) - 
    • Presence of lupus anticoagulant, or
    • Anticardiolipin antibodies, or
    • Anti-β2 glycoprotein antibody

Specific therapy in pregnancy: Aspirin plus heparin therapy is the most effective regimen. Women are treated with low-dose aspirin and heparin for up to 34 weeks. Unfractionated heparin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) are equally effective and safe. Corticosteroids are used only in secondary APLA syndrome (associated with SLE) and not in primary APLA syndrome. 

Prophylaxis:

  • Women with prior thromboembolic events - prophylactic anticoagulation throughout pregnancy and six weeks postpartum with either heparin are recommended. Serial sonographic assessment of fetal growth and antepartum testing should be done in the third trimester due to the risk of fetal growth abnormalities and stillbirths.
  • For women without prior thromboembolic events, acceptable regimes include - 
    • Close antepartum maternal observation with or without prophylactic heparin along with postpartum anticoagulation for 4 to 6 weeks or
    • Surveillance alone, or
    • Prophylactic heparin + low dose aspirin (if a prior history of recurrent abortion or stillbirth)

Note: The new 2023 ACR/EULAR criteria is an update from the revised Sapporo criteria with the clinical criteria, which includes an entry criterion of at least one positive antiphospholipid antibody within three years of identification of a clinical criterion, followed by scoring with weighted criteria divided into six clinical domains (macrovascular venous thromboembolism, macrovascular arterial thrombosis, microvascular, obstetric, cardiac valve, and hematologic) and two laboratory domains (lupus anticoagulant,  IgG/IgM anticardiolipin ELISA and/or IgG/IgM anti-β2 -glycoprotein I antibodies) This has increased the specificity in diagnosing APS.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cardinal finding in patients who are declared brain dead according to Harvard criteria for brain death?

choices.text: No pupillary changes in response to light
Absent eye movements in response to caloric testing

questions.solution:
Cough response to bronchial suction is indicative of normal cough reflex and is, therefore not a cardinal finding in brain death. 

The 3 cardinal features of brain death include:

  1. Unresponsiveness or coma- demonstrated by an absent motor response to pain in all extremities.
  2. Apnea- impaired brainstem activity indicates damage to the medullary cardio-respiratory centers. This manifests as a loss of centrally controlled breathing.
  3. Absence of brainstem reflexes -
    • Cranial nerve II, III (optic and oculomotor)- absent direct and consensual light reflex. This is associated with dilated pupils measuring about 9 mm. 
    • Cranial nerve VIII (vestibulocochlear)- absent oculocephalic (Doll's eye phenomenon) and oculovestibular (unresponsive to caloric testing) reflexes.
    • Cranial nerve V, VII (trigeminal and facial)- absent corneal and jaw reflexes.
    • Cranial nerve IX, X (glossopharyngeal and vagus)- absent cough and gag reflexes.

Related Pearl: Harvard criteria for brain death

  • No movements    
  • Apnoea        
  • Absence of elicitable reflexes      
  • Isoelectric EEG (confirmatory)

questions.text: A 58-year-old man underwent an orthopedic procedure following which he was taking multiple antibiotics. He later developed fever, diarrhoea and abdominal pain. Blood investigations reveal leukocytosis. Pseudomembranous colitis is suspected. The criteria for the diagnosis of the suspected condition includes all except?

choices.text: Detection of toxin A or B in stool
Stool wet mount microscopy to visualise the organism
Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days)

questions.solution:
Stool wet mount microscopy to visualize the organism is not part of the criteria for the diagnosis of pseudomembranous colitis

Pathologically, the organism produces two toxins; Toxin A(Enterotoxin) causing large-volume diarrhea, and Toxin B(Cytotoxin) causing epithelial injury and bloody stools.

The endoscopic image below shows pseudomembranous colitis caused by Clostridium difficile infection (CDI). It is most commonly associated with the use of antimicrobials like cephalosporin, ampicillin, fluoroquinolones, clindamycin, etc.

The diagnosis is based on a combination of 2 criteria:
1. Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days)
2. Detection of toxins A & B in stools, detection of toxin-producing C. difficile by NAAT/Culture, Visualisation of the pseudomembrane in the colon.

questions.text: According to Truelove–Witts criteria, which of the following is not a criterion to diagnose acute severe colitis?
questions.solution:
The presence of jaundice and pruritus is not a part of Truelove–Witts criteria which are used to define acute severe ulcerative colitis. 

Truelove–Witts criteria define acute severe colitis as the presence of:

  1. ≥ 6 bloody stools/24 hrs
  2. Plus, one or more of the following features:
    • Anemia (Hemoglobin <10 g/dL).
    • Mild fever (>100.04°F).
    • Tachycardia (Pulse ≥90 beats/min).
    • High inflammatory markers (ESR > 30 mm/hr or CRP >30 mg/L).
